awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Aquatic debris cleanup using multi-agent unmanned surface vehicles and hotspot-based path optimization
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to benefit US shorelines. The World Economic Forum predicts that by 2050 there will be more plastic than fish in the world's oceans. Waterfront maintenance workers face the brunt of the marine trash pollution issue as 80% of marine trash is sourced near-shore. As a result, waterfront governments alone spend a total of $10.2 billion to clean these waterways. The proposed technology benefits ecosystems by removing trash pollution from our shores, thereby preventing ecosystem degradation and allowing people to both benefit from marine services now and in the future. 

This I-Corps project introduces the use of Unmanned Surface Vehicles (USV) to maximize debris cleanup performance and provide affordable solutions to cleaning these waterways. Solutions are being developed to address the oceanic plastic pollution problem once the debris is already in the ocean; however, insufficient effort is directed towards improving shoreline pickup, which contains 80% of plastic debris. Human-operated methods to collect the debris is inefficient and cost ineffective. This opens the door to expand USV technology to waterway maintenance. Similarly, USV environmental monitoring capabilities may provide data to the waterways and researchers such as oxygen monitoring for algae blooms and affordable data capture. The team currently has a working prototype and partnerships at the Jacobs School of Engineering and Scripps Institution of Oceanography. The I-Corps customer discovery activities will reveal the exact pain points experienced in these waterways to inform the proposed technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Remora began the NSF I-Corps program with a vision to address the expanding global plastic pollution crisis in our waterways. To do so, we set out to develop autonomous, surface-skimming aquadrones to navigate waterways and collect debris. At the time we did not have the strongest grasp of what our final devices would look like and where they would be best deployed, let alone what the market looked like and how to shape a successful business model. What we did know was that the need was present: 1.4 billion tons of trash enters the ocean every year and 80% of it first touches the water near-shore. This shaped our initial design to be focused on providing services to municipalities who steward these local waterways. While the COVID-19 pandemic had made our growth challenging, we were able to make solid progress.

Being trained as engineers, the team started the program with limited formal background on business model development, market fit strategies, and other skills required to identify viability of our idea and build a sustainable business. The NSF I-Corp program provided the resources, mentorship, and guidance to help bridge that gap. As a result, a major goal of ours was to understand our place in the market. 

We have spent significant time fine-tuning the business model canvas through continued market research and customer interviews. The NSF funds provided us with the financial support to spend the hours necessary to schedule, engage, and analyze interviews with stakeholders around the world. Through this process, we had a few key takeaways: non-profit organizations are the leading group performing waterway cleanup, Downstream water bodies (such as ports and harbors) focus on stormwater systems and education while Upstream water bodies (such as lakes, rivers) do spend on implementing trash capture. We also found that some lake municipalities spend over 15% of staff time picking up floating trash and stationary trash collection methods are great for moving bodies of water like rivers. As a result, lakes in upstream water bodies was shown to be a good fit for the approach that our USV takes. This helped us conclude that lakes are likely our beachhead market and is now guiding a shift in further customer discovery while also helping us narrow down the design elements that are most important to these customers. 

The issue of plastic pollution in our waterways has only grown since we started the NSF I-Corps program and we as a team still have more progress to make in order to roll out our solution. Our next steps are to continue customer interviews focused specifically on lakes to enhance our understanding of the product-market fit in this customer segment, refine our pricing model, and further identify the issues that they face. We are also planning to attend more issue-focused conferences which will allow us to continue our technical research and identify which of our product capabilities align with customer value propositions. On the engineering side, we will be continuing R&D of the structure, collection, and propulsion systems along with growing our computer vision and machine learning models to expand autonomy. The NSF I-Corps program did a great job at providing us with the resources to develop the fundamentals of the devices, grow the company and business model, and bring us one step closer to rolling out our solution to address the growing environmental issue of plastic pollution.


Last Modified: 09/21/2022
Modified by: Jan Kleissl
